After revolutionizing the television landscape with its streaming service, Netflix began unveiling its own original shows in 2013, with House of Cards becoming the company’s first hit single of sorts. More popular shows were soon to follow, and today the company is only gaining momentum. The current stable of Netflix Originals includes a massive number of scripted and documentary series produced in-house or co-produced with other studios specifically for Netflix — and that’s not even counting the gobs of other programs on Netflix, including many for which the company holds exclusive streaming rights. With such a diverse pool of originals to choose from, you might be wondering: Which of these shows are worth watching for 11 straight hours this weekend? That’s where we come in. I’ve assembled a list of the best Netflix Original series available right now. ‘AMERICAN VANDAL’ After 27 cars in the high-school faculty’s parking lot are vandalized with crude phallic images, the school’s resident slacker and class clown is expelled, but when two fellow students initiate a documentary-style investigation into the incident, suddenly everyone becomes a suspect in this surprisingly compelling and hilarious series. A satire of true-crime documentaries like Making a Murdererand Serial, American Vandal is a mockumentary that manages to channel much of the same “Did he really do it?” uncertainty into its story, while also offering a very funny and impressively clever spin on the typical docuseries format. Much like the true-crime series that inspired it, the first season of American Vandal is packed with narrative twists and turns that keep the audience guessing. It’s supremely binge-friendly as you push to discover the next revelation in this seemingly minor incident that consumes the lives of the characters involved in it. The first season of the series earned rave reviews, prompting Netflix to commission a second season, which premiered September 14 to even more critical acclaim. Sadly, that might be the last we see of the series, as Netflix abruptly canceled it in October as part of a wave of cancellations of projects Netflix co-produced with other studios. ‘BIG MOUTH’ If you can handle a little bit (OK, a lot) of potty humor, you should enjoy Big Mouth.The animated series follows two seventh graders, Nick and Andrew (series creator Nick Kroll and John Mulaney, respectively), as they struggle with their burgeoning sexuality, represented by a grotesque, crass “hormone monster” (also voiced by Kroll), whose base desires cause turmoil and frustration for both boys. Their friends Jessi (Jessi Klein) and Jay (Jason Mantzoukas) also struggle with puberty to varying degrees, as does Andrew’s crush, Missy (Jenny Slate). On its surface, Big Mouth is quite crude, but that humor belies the show’s nuanced, relatable exploration of adolescence. The series deftly handles the difficulties of middle school life, including common misconceptions held by kids about their sexuality and their body. The second season of Big Mouthpremiered October 5, and the series was renewed for a third season the following month. ‘BLACK MIRROR’ What happens when technology goes too far? That’s not an unreasonable question to ask oneself in 2018, and Black Mirror(originally broadcast on British Channel 4, before being acquired by Netflix) is a wildly entertaining, if depressing, answer to that question. Most of the episodes of this chilling anthology series ponder hypothetical eventualities resulting from the unchecked advancement of technology, often charting courses that are disturbingly well-connected to the way we work and live today. The show’s production value keeps getting better, and the third and fourth seasons — produced by Netflix — include a bevy of household names, from Jesse Plemons to Gugu Mbatha-Raw (whom creator/writer Charlie Brooker uses to great effect). The first two seasons — including the epic Christmas special White Christmas — are also must-see programming. ‘BOJACK HORSEMAN’ Despite lukewarm reviews for its first season, BoJack improved dramatically and received critical acclaim for the following three campaigns. The animated show centers around BoJack Horseman (Will Arnett), a washed-up ’90s sitcom star (and actual horse-man) trying to find happiness and reclaim his former fame. Anthropomorphic half-breeds are the norm, and the show milks much of its humor by simply playing off stereotypes associated with the characters’ animal halves. The show’s true strength lies in its sincerity, however, as BoJack struggles to deal with his insecurities in a town rife with celebrity and its many vapid failings. Paul F. Tompkins (Best Week Ever), Alison Brie (Community, GLOW), and Aaron Paul (Breaking Bad) provide excellent voice support in a series that flips from hilarious to depressing with impressive grace. The series was renewed for a sixth season in October 2018. ‘CHEF’S TABLE’ This documentary web series introduces viewers to top culinary minds across the world, offering insight into the day-to-day experiences and responsibilities of renowned chefs. Each episode focuses on a different restauranteur and blends together personal stories with culinary content to great effect. The show’s traditional documentary presentation can be a bit stuffy at times, and the narratives can be unevenly balanced in favor of emotional backstories, but most viewers should enjoy and appreciate some insight into the wide world of fine dining. The quality of each episode hinges largely upon the personality of the chosen chef, and some — notably Massimo Bottura in the first season, Dominique Crenn in the second, and the brash Ivan Orkin in the third — are more camera-friendly than others. Still, the series is a welcome departure from the competition-focused cooking shows that dominate cable and network TV. If you like this, Chef’s Table France is also worth seeing. ‘THE CROWN’ The Crown is perhaps the best show on television right now, period. Easily the most celebrated British period piece since Downton Abbey, The Crown follows Queen Elizabeth II — the still-reigning Queen of England, at 91 years old — across different periods of her life, beginning with her 1947 marriage to Prince Philip of Edinburgh. Reception to the series has been overwhelmingly positive, as nearly ever aspect of the show — acting, production value, historical accuracy — has been widely praised. The series’ interesting format sees Netflix recasting the role of Elizabeth and other characters season-to-season; Claire Foy starred in seasons one and two alongside Matt Smith (Dr. Who) and Vanessa Kirby, while we know Olivia Colman (Peep Show) will be taking the reins in season three (with Helena Bonham Carter set to portray Princess Margaret as well). Netflix plans to produce a total of 60 episodes over six seasons. ‘DAREDEVIL’ The first in a slew of Marvel shows to hit Netflix over the past few years, Daredevil stands largely on the strength of Charlie Cox’s performance in the title role. Cast in a similar vein as Christopher Nolan’s Batman movies, this series shows a darker side to Marvel Studios’ colorful cast of superheroes. The blind vigilante spends his days protecting New York City’s Hell’s Kitchen as a lawyer, and his nights doing the same in a much more tangible (and violent) manner. The show’s action sequences are fun, and amiable supporting performances from Elden Henson (The Mighty Ducks) and Deborah Ann Woll (True Blood) bring some comic relief and heart to the bleak setting, but as usual, the real stars of the show are the villains. Vincent D’Onofrio is excellent as the deranged Kingpin, while Jon Bernthal’s turn as the Punisher — which earned him his own Netflix series — is as convincing as it is visceral. Season 3 of the series premiered October 19 and earned widespread praise, with some calling it the best season of the series so far. Sadly, the series was canceled by Netflix shortly after the debut of season 3 as part of its efforts to reduce the number of series it co-produces with other studios. ‘DARK’ As the only foreign-language entry on our list, Dark would merit some curiosity at the very least, but it’s here not because it’s German, but because it’s awesome. A Stranger Things-esque setup — missing children from a small town, supernatural occurrences, mysterious laboratories — will have you thinking you know what to expect, but trust us, you don’t. The town of Winden lives in the shadow of eternal clouds, lending Dark a more macabre vibe than Stranger Things, which peppers in comic sequences and lots of nostalgia. Dark weaves together multiple storylines amid complex relationships endemic to small-town life, even outside the good, old U.S. of A. If you’re in the mood for a lighthearted romp or a satisfying romance arc, move on — this is not the show for you. But if you love serious shows with a flair for the dramatic (and a heaping helping of despair). ‘DEAR WHITE PEOPLE’ After Justin Simien’s 2014 film of the same name earned rave reviews, Netflix commissioned the young director for a multiseason TV series, featuring the same characters (recast) and an altered storyline. The series is about black students at a predominantly white (and fictitious) Ivy League college, Winchester University, who work to try and find both group and individual identities while carving out a place within the school’s ecosystem. Logan Browning stars as Sam White, a student who runs a radio show titled Dear White People, which causes some controversy among the student body. Thanks to Simien’s expert touch, the show deftly handles the nuances of identity, romance, education, and socialization with plenty of comedic moments, helping to inform viewers of all colors about other points of view without ever seeming judgmental or vindictive. The second season premiered in May 2018, and the series was renewed for a third season the next month. ‘EASY’ This anthology series, created by mumblecore hotshot Joe Swanberg (Win It All), provides a template for relatable and realistic depictions of love and sex in the 21st century. Despite a star-studded list of performers — including Orlando Bloom, Emily Ratajkowski, and Dave Franco, to name a few — Swanberg manages to make you forget that you’re watching someone famous by crafting characters that are deep, yet not too complicated to fit into a 30-minute window. Each vignette catalogs the struggles of a couple or group of people in contemporary Chicago, where gender roles and language barriers are equal obstacles for people seeking happiness. The show’s brevity prevents most of the stories from reaching any sort of satisfying conclusion, but it’s a sincere collection of not-so-tall tales that most will find familiar and engaging. If you watch through both seasons, there are even some neat callbacks. ‘GLOW’ Stop us if you’ve heard this one before: A down-on-her-luck actress in the mid-1980s (Alison Brie) finds surprising fulfillment when she joins a low-budget women’s wrestling program run by a seedy, dishonest director (Marc Maron). Oh, what’s that? You’ve never seen anything like this? Duh. GLOW — which stands for Gorgeous Ladies Of Wrestling — was a real show in the mid-80s that featured wrestling (of course), wacky and colorful characters, and crazy comedy sketches. Netflix’s take on it sees the ladies of GLOW battling their own personal issues while trying to come together and produce a successful show; it’s a dangerous premise, but one that works incredibly well thanks to dedicated performances from Brie, Maron, and Betty Gelpin. British rocker Kate Nash, Sydelle Noel, and Britney Young are also excellent in supporting roles. Season 2 premiered in June to positive reviews, and the series was renewed for a third season in August 2018. ‘THE HAUNTING OF HILL HOUSE’ This terrifying series from Mike Flanagan, the writer and director of criminally under-appreciated horror films Oculus and Ouija: Origin of Evil, offers a new spin on Shirley Jackson’s 1959 novel of the same name. It follows a family who moves into an old house intending to renovate it, only to experience one scary paranormal event after another before a mysterious tragedy forces them out of the haunted manor. The story unfolds through a mix of timeline-hopping explorations of each family member’s experiences at Hill House and years later, as the trauma of those encounters shapes their lives and eventually brings them back to where it all started. Beautifully shot, expertly paced, and filled with the sort of subtle call-backs that encourage multiple viewings, The Haunting of Hill House is one of the best horror tales to debut on any screen — big or small — in recent years. Oh, and if you don’t believe us, just consider that Stephen King himself described the series as “close to a work of genius.” ‘JESSICA JONES’ Krysten Ritter shines as antihero Jessica Jones, who rejected her superhero persona after a traumatic experience at the hands of Kilgrave (David Tennant), and now runs her own detective agency. Like Daredevil, the series is darker and more grounded than Marvel’s cinematic efforts, though it’s missing some of the goofy lighthearted qualities that Daredevilbrings. Jessica Jones is thematically heavier, as the characters deal with topics like rape and PTSD. As with Daredevil, the villain is the sizzle of this first season — Tennant’s take on the villain Kilgrave conjures perhaps the best performance of any on-screen Marvel bad guy this side of Tom Hiddleston’s Loki. The show’s structure seems uniquely suited for the future inclusion of guest heroes; Luke Cage figures prominently in the first season, while season 2 has its own intriguing new characters to build upon. Both Jones and Cage (along with Daredevil and Iron Fist) featured heavily in Netflix’s crossover series The Defenders. The third season is expected to premiere in 2019. ‘LOST IN SPACE’ The latest adaptation of Irwin Allen’s landmark 1960s sci-fi series, Lost In Spaceis centered on the Robinson family, which has taken to the stars together, courtesy of a program aimed at finding a new home for humanity. Of course, their craft veers off course and they end up in a new galaxy entirely, leading — as you might expect — to a series of dangerous scenarios in which the family must work together to survive. Toby Stephens (Black Sails) plays army-dad John Robinson, whose wife (Maureen) is the expedition leader. The kids are played by Taylor Russell, Mina Sundwall, and Maxwell Jenkins, with support from Parker Posey, Ignacio Serrichio, and more. While it’s the same old take on The Swiss Family Robinson at its core, the series’ special effects, set design, and cinematography are all top-notch, lending a sense of legitimacy to the many perils faced by the space Robinsons & co. Perhaps more importantly, the family dynamic — especially with the three children and the robot Will befriends — feels real, turning this from an also-ran space sitcom into a pretty great show. ‘MASTER OF NONE’ If you’ve never seen an episode of Master of None, you might be surprised to see star/creator Aziz Ansari depart from his trademark style of comedy — namely, loud, ridiculous, and goofy — and try on an outfit that looks brand new, but somehow feels worn-in. The show follows Dev Shah (Ansari), a not-so-famous actor living in New York (then, later, Italy) who is simply trying to get by. Master of Noneoffers a unique and honest take on comedy that’s less reliant on punchlines and more situational — it’s Louie, with a Millennial twist. Some episodes are funny, while some are sad, but the majority of them feel well-written and natural. Noël Wells and Eric Wareheim (Tim and Eric Awesome Show) provide some help off the bench, and while the acting can occasionally feel a bit strained (especially in the first season), Ansari’s crisp writing and relatable performances (he won a Golden Globe for his efforts) truly carry the show. Aziz’s real parents also appear as Dev’s parents in several hilarious segments, displaying comedy chops that must be hereditary. ‘MINDHUNTER’ Why do we obsess over serial killers? Perhaps it’s because we don’t truly understand what makes them tick. That’s the hook for Mindhunter, a crime drama with executive production credits for both David Fincher (Fight Club, Gone Girl) and Charlize Theron. Jonathan Groff (Glee, Hamilton) and Holt McCallany play FBI agents tasked with interviewing and assessing serial killers in order to build personality profiles which might help solve ongoing and future cases. Aside from Anna Torv (Fringe), a largely anonymous cast takes the stage here, as the pair of agents investigates and interviews real killers from the mid-late 20th century, including one Ed Kemper. Mindhunter is largely a bleak affair, with a general sense of dread pushed forward by creepy performances and graphic crime scene photos. Still, it’s a curious subject and one which informs the detective work done by characters in modern cop dramas. If you liked Nightcrawler, Zodiac, and Silence of the Lambs, you’ll like Mindhunter. ‘NARCOS’ Yes, Pablo Escobar is played out, and the show takes its fair share of historical liberties. However, any quibbles with this series can easily be pardoned thanks to some absolutely brilliant performances by Wagner Moura (Escobar) and Boyd Holbrook (Steve Murphy), the latter of which is on his way to becoming a bona fide action star thanks to turns in the excellent Logan and The Predator. Narcos details Escobar’s rise to wealth and power as the face behind one of the largest drug cartels of all time, based out of Medellin, Colombia. Moura oscillates between dedicated family man and ruthless kingpin with alarming ease, while DEA agents Murphy and Javier Peña (Pedro Pascal) work to capture the elusive patron. If you’re unfamiliar with Escobar’s story, this is a riveting (if not wholly realistic) look into the man, and the chaos he wrought upon an entire continent during his heyday. The third season follows a sister cartel after Escobar’s death (uh … spoilers?). The popularity of the series even led to a spinoff series, Narcos: Mexico, which premiered in November. ‘ON MY BLOCK’ Saying that Hollywood has issues of representation would be the world’s biggest understatement, but with On My Block, Netflix is working to remedy those issues. The show follows four high school freshmen — all people of color — in a witty, relatable coming-of-age story which culminates in some tensely dramatic moments. Monse (Sierra Capri) is a tomboy with deep-seated feelings for one of her close friends, Cesar (Diego Tinoco), who’s trying to balance an unstable home life against the social demands of school and his feelings for Monse. Ruby (Jason Genao) is a whip-smart smooth talker, Jamal (Brett Gray) is a nerd on a quest, and Olivia (Ronni Hawk) is trying to make things work after her family is deported. The series treats ethnic and cultural divides with grace, showing how difficult it is to grow up as a young person of color in America.

Disclaimer: I haven’t watched a lot of “recommended” Netflix originals like Orange is the New Black, Narcos, House of Cards, The Crown etc. My recommendations are purely based on the ones I have.  #1: Stranger Things An absolutely wonderful show with a talented cast, a gripping sci-fi narrative, and wholesome entertainment. Stranger Things was a sleeper hit for Netflix and has propelled its young stars and creators (Duffer brothers) to fame. If you loved the horror, thriller, sci-fi movies of the 80s and 90s, you are in for a treat. #2: Daredevil and Jessica Jones (plus the broader Marvel TV Universe) Daredevil’s first season was stunning. It literally was like a Nolan-esque TV adaptation of the Devil of Hell’s Kitchen. Vincent D’Onofrio’s Kingpin is easily one of the most compelling supervillains brought to life. The addition of Jon Bernthal’s Punisher to the mix in Seasons 2 and 3 was an added bonus. The same can be said of Jessica Jones which was more of a cop drama/crime thriller. Again, the primary villain of the introductory season, Jebediah Kilgrave aka the Purple Man, brought to life by the ex-Doctor, David Tennant was terrifying. The other 3 series are also decent for a one-time watch. Luke Cage’s Season 1 had a really great first half, however, it sort of fizzled out towards the end. Luke Cage was lukewarm. Defenders was a decent first outing for the “street-level Avengers”. #3: Bojack Horseman I had been reading a lot on Reddit about the show and was fairly intrigued. Season 1 was OK, but they really kicked in up in the next 3. Needless to say, describing Bojack Horseman as “a show revolving around an anthromorphic junkie horse, who used to be a famous TV star but is now just a bitter, cynical, self-loathing jerk” doesn’t do it justice. Over the course of 4 seasons, the show has subtly addressed many issues that are generally brushed aside - the perils of child stardom, the ramifications of drug abuse, heartbreak, dementia, non-heterosexual relationships, a sneak peek into the lives of independent women, parenting. The 9th episodes of the seasons 3 and 4 had me in tears. #4: Rick and Morty I absolutely loathe the Rick and Morty fandom for how utterly obnoxious and unbearable they are, but that doesn’t take away anything from the show. Loosely based on the “Back to the Future” premise, R&M is a wonderful binge-watch. #5: Big Mouth This popped into my recommendations when I finished R&M and Bojack. And IMO (for all it matters), it is a fairly unique show dealing with the nuances of teenage years (and not the ones the Nickelodeon shows focus on). Unfazed and unabashed (with the occasional sprinkle of fourth-wall breaking humor), Big Mouth talks about the more tabooed side of the teenage spurt years - masturbation, discovering one’s sexual identity, the first awkward kiss, the perils of porn addiction, young relationships in the age of social media etc. I wish BM was around a decade and a half back. #6: Wet Hot American Summer (First Day of Camp + 10 Years Later) I loved the goofy old camp movie and when they decided to do a prequel as well as a sequel series to it, I couldn’t resist. Both the series are 8 hours of nonsensical fun. #7: F is for Family Another show where I didn’t expect much. You might get the occasional Simpsons or Family Guy vibe from it. But FifF has its unique niche and does a good job of portraying the family dynamics in the 80s.  P.S. I have heard great reviews about Mindhunter, Friends From College, GLOW, Master of None, and Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt and plan to soon watch them. Hemlock Grove was also a decent watch but I could not keep up after the second season. Finally, the stand-up show, The Characters is a refreshing change for the fans of the live comic scene.

I would say any that look interesting to you. Netflix doesn’t often make low-quality content. I’ll offer my favorites, since I know about them. Marvel’s Daredevil - Dark, gritty and violent, but also smooth and sleek. Very well made vigilante series. Basically a poor and blind(ish) Batman. Marvel’s Iron Fist - After I watched this, I was really surprised by the poor reviews it go. The psychology in it is so good. It’s an action-oriented show with focus on bastardizations of martial arts customs, but they did the psychology so well. The main character, Danny Rand was taken, as a child and after a hugely traumatic event, to a city where he was taught to avoid and repress his emotions. When he comes back, he’s a mess. Still basically the nine year old he left as in a lot of ways and it shows. More than that, when he gets frustrated and can’t communicate effectively, I got frustrated with him, because of how masterfully the scenes were manipulated. Marvel’s The Defenders - A culmination of Daredevil, Iron Fist, Luke Cage and Jessica Jones with just enough of each of them, just enough of each of their supporting characters, a mostly great plot (I had one issue that bothered me enough to mention it exists) and none of the polarizing plot points that any of them may have. If you like any one of them, I imagine you’ll very likely enjoy this. Marco Polo - Unfortunately this gem was cut short, ending after season 2, due to production costs being so high, but that cost definitely shows. Very fun and interesting fictional take on the real-life explorer. It’s got a spin-off short movie for one of its characters titled One Hundred Eyes. Medici - I consider this an attempt at being a spiritual successor to Marco Polo, but it definitely very much has its own identity. It’s very fun, engaging and self-aware. to include a wonderful, subtly humorous scene between Richard Madden and David Bradley. Frontier - A take on the Canadian frontier of colonial North America. It’s a pretty interesting plot made to appeal to teenagers as much as adults. It’s got a darkness and aggression to it that I feel is similar to BBC’s Luther. Mindhunter - A very charming and fun show that takes on the 70s efforts into expanding psychology and doing away with social stigmas of even talking about certain topics. Specifically, the main characters are FBI agents who travel around the country talking to remarkably well portrayed real-life serial killers to gather information on the psychology that causes people to become serial killers, but also tackles other topics that were and are very much taboo. Castlevania - This one’s a bit iffy. It’s anime styled, which wasn’t an issue for me. I often find myself wishing there were good anime, because I like the animation style. So, this was a pleasant surprise in that regard. The biggest issue with this is the pacing. It’s very much made for binge watching, but only offers 4 episodes for the first season. Otherwise it’s great. A well told story based on the lore of the long-running game series of the same name. Pretty cool vampire meets amazing woman and things get crazy from there. Fuller House - It basically just makes fun of everything. Especially itself. Easiest and most comfortable thing I’ve found to watch since Roseanne.

Netflix is making the vaunted Nielsen television rating system obsolete. It is is forcing cable companies to change the way they do business. When Netflix began competing with TV networks directly for original content, it became a more attractive destination for showrunners and script writers because it offered upfront contracts to create an entire season or two. This led to some pretty amazing TV series being launched which changed how we saw TV. House of Cards - IMDB Rating - 9.0 - Frank Underwood is a Democrat appointed as the Secretary of State. Along with his wife, he sets out on a quest to seek revenge from the people who betrayed him while successfully rising to supremacy.  Black Mirror - IMDB Rating - 8.9 - An anthology series that revolves around a group of people's personal lives and how technology manipulates their behaviour. It is centred around dark and satirical themes that examine modern society, particularly with regard to the unanticipated consequences of new technologies. Each episode is a different story. Each episode has a different cast, a different setting, even a different reality. But they're all about the way we live now – and the way we might be living in 10 minutes' time if we're clumsy.  Stranger Things - IMDB Rating - 8.9 - When Joyce's 12-year-old son, Will, goes missing, she launches a terrifying investigation into his disappearance with local authorities. As they search for answers, they unravel a series of extraordinary mysteries involving secret government experiments, unnerving supernatural forces, and a very unusual little girl.  Narcos - IMDB Rating - 8.9 - The gritty drama begins with the early days of the drug battle, when the biggest offenders were "hippies in flip-flops" caught with up to a kilo of marijuana, continuing to the violent, bloody battles between members of the cartel peddling tons of kilos of cocaine and drug agents from Colombia, Mexico, and the U.S. -- a struggle estimated to have cost at least 4,000 lives over two decades.  The Crown - IMDB Rating - 8.8 - The series begins with an inside look at the early reign of the queen, who ascended the throne at age 25 after the death of her father, King George VI. As the decades pass, personal intrigues, romances, and political rivalries are revealed that played a big role in events that shaped the later years of the 20th century.  Marvel's Daredevil - IMDB Rating - 8.7 - Blinded in an accident as a child, Matt Murdock uses his heightened senses as Daredevil to fight crime on the streets of New York after the sun goes down. While Murdock's day job requires him to believe in the criminal justice system, his alter ego does not follow suit, leading him to take the law into his own hands to protect his Hell's Kitchen neighbourhood and the surrounding communities.  Making a Murderer - IMDB Rating - 8.7 - Exonerated after spending nearly two decades in prison for a crime he did not commit, Steven Avery filed suit against Manitowoc County, Wis., and several individuals involved with his arrest. Shortly after, however, Avery found himself behind bars again, this time accused of the murder of 25-year-old photographer Teresa Halbach. She was last seen on Avery's property, where she was to photograph a vehicle. Avery and nephew Brendan Dassey were tried and (spoiler alert) convicted of the crime. But that's not the end of the story.  13 Reasons Why - IMDB Rating - 8.6 - Two weeks after Hannah’s tragic suicide, a classmate named Clay finds a mysterious box on his porch. Inside the box are recordings made by Hannah -- on whom Clay had a crush -- in which she explains the 13 reasons why she chose to commit suicide. If Clay decides to listen to the recordings, he will find out if and how he made the list.  BoJack Horseman - IMDB Rating - 8.4 - A humanoid horse, BoJack Horseman -- lost in a sea of self-loathing and booze -- decides it's time for a comeback. Once the star of a '90s sitcom, in which he was the adoptive father of three orphaned kids (two girls and a boy). The show was the hottest thing around, then suddenly, was canceled. Now 18 years later, BoJack wants to regain his dignity. With the aid of a human sidekick and a feline ex-girlfriend who is his agent, he sets out to make it happen. But Hollywood is vastly different from those days, and getting used to stuff like Twitter may take some time.  Sense8 - IMDB Rating - 8.4 - Eight strangers around the globe find themselves connected -- first by a violent vision, then by their shared ability to connect with one another's thoughts and actions, and finally by the urgent need to find out what happened and why. Their need to know goes beyond simple curiosity -- as they pursue answers, a mysterious organization hunts them down, intent on destroying them.  Master of None - IMDB Rating - 8.3 - Aziz Ansari plays the role of Dev, a New York-based actor who is struggling to identify what he really wants, both personally and professionally. The series reveals glimpses of Dev's younger years, and explores current aspects of his life, including modern etiquette (regarding texting and social media), and being young and single in the city. Other important people in Dev's life are featured, including Dev's dad, played by Ansari's actual father.  Orange Is the New Black - IMDB Rating - 8.2 - Ten years after transporting drug money to Alex, Piper is imprisoned for the crime. The toughness of prison changes her drastically as an individual, compelling her to do the unthinkable.  Marvel's Jessica Jones - IMDB Rating - 8.2 - When a tragedy puts an the end to her short-lived career as a superhero, Jessica Jones settles in New York City and opens her own detective agency, called Alias Investigations, which seems to be called into cases involving people who have special abilities. Suffering from post-traumatic stress syndrome, Jessica wants to do good, but her primary interest isn't in saving the world, it's saving her apartment and getting through each day.  A Series of Unfortunate Events - IMDB Rating - 7.9 - The tragic tale of three orphans -- Violet, Klaus, and Sunny Baudelaire -- who are investigating their parents' mysterious death. The siblings are saddled with an evil guardian named Count Olaf, who will do whatever it takes to get his hands on the Baudelaire's inheritance. Violet, Klaus, and Sunny must outsmart Olaf at every turn, foiling devious plans and disguises.  These are the very best that Netflix has got to offer viewers. House of Cards, Black Mirror, Stranger Things, Narcos, Daredevil, Making a Murderer, BoJack Horseman and Orange is The New Black are must-watches!!!  Sources: Wikipedia & Google Images

Bojack Horseman It’s hard for me to pick one favorite Netflix original, but if I have to, then it’s Bojack. At a glance, this looks like another adult animated black comedy drama, except It’s not. I’m hooked with the main character, Bojack Horseman (brilliantly voiced by Will Arnett) since the pilot. Never thought I’d say this but the adult topics (mid-life crisis, abusive parents, fatherhood, and fame goes wrong) are just too deep, it makes me thinking about life.  You’ll love it because: the celebrity cameo is more fun than The Simpsons. Some of them voice their own characters (even Sir Paul McCartney!) Some “cameo” have really funny names.  Don’t get me started with a spider director named Quentin Tarantulino.. For more fun: 136 Hidden Jokes You Probably Missed On "BoJack Horseman" LOVE Nothing special about the girl meets boy plot, but the two main characters are too different (imagine Napoleon Dynamite meets Julia Stiles’ whiny character in 10 Things I Hate About You). The juxtaposition is very interesting to watch. Judd Apatow is one of the creators. Great cast too. What’s not to LOVE?  The Crown We have seen many portrayals of the Queen, from Helen Mirren to Kristin Scott Thomas, but I have never seen a series dedicated to explore further about the Queen’s life. So when Netflix released The Crown in 2016, I tried to watch it in two or three sittings. Turned out it’s pretty challenging because every time I finished an episode, I browsed the historical facts and awed with the accuracy. I’m a sucker for history, so knowing it has many historical details, I took my time to do historical check after finishing every episode. It doesn’t disappoint.  You’ll love it because: the cast are amazing. Go to this video at 6:00 to see how Alex Jennings who played Edward VIII imitated the original speech accurately, even the pauses!  Big Mouth  No series on Netflix talks puberty more than Big Mouth. This adult animated coming of age is one of series that I wish I watched when I was a teenager. It covers menstruation, sexual arousal, basically something we all can relate. This should be featured in How to Survive Puberty kit for teenagers. Errr.. or maybe not really since it’s rated NR. You’ll love it because: the female hormone monster is voiced by Maya Rudolph! Everything Sucks!  Spoiler alert: it doesn’t suck at all. Took place in Oregon, 1996 it tells about students life in Boring High School - yes that’s the name. Pay attention to the cool soundtrack (from Oasis to Weezer) that will take you time travel to the 90’s. It has a good lesson about finding your sexuality in teenage years too. Definitely something the young generation need to watch. Fun fact: the popular girl character is portrayed by Sydney Sweeney, Eden from The Handmaid’s Tale! Mindhunter  Normally, crime drama is not my cup of tea, but when I heard it’s directed by David Fincher, then I don’t have any excuse to miss this one. It’s based on a book written by former FBI agent. Personally, I can relate to Holden Ford’s character, so it’s really fun to watch and guess what he’d do next. You’ll love it because: The series features real serial killer characters and you’ll learn more about the FBI investigating and interviewing techniques. Some scenes are too graphic for me, though. Master of None I have been a fan of Aziz Ansari since 2011. I religiously follow his stand ups and writing, so this is a no brainer.  There are actors like Zooey Deschannel, Johnny Depp, and Helena Bonham Carter who no matter how hard they try, they end up playing themselves. Aziz Ansari is one of them. Not saying it’s bad, because if you watch Master of None and read his book, Modern Romance at the same time, somehow you’ll get the impression the series is a visualization of the book; they compliment each other. Fun fact: Dev’s parents are Ansari’s real life parents! Black Mirror Black Mirror is the most mind-blowing series I’ve ever watched. For slow watchers, the good thing is you can watch the episodes separately. All episodes focus on technology. Some episodes hit too close to home, some are more outstanding than the others.  Tips from me: skip the first episode in the first season. You can watch it later, because it has different concept with the whole series and you’ll get the wrong impression about the series if you start from that one. The Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt  Everybody loves a happy-go-lucky girl show, especially when there’s a bit of musical and Ellie Kemper’s in it. This is my go-to show when I spent 10 minutes on Netflix’s homepage trying to find something relaxing to watch, thinking Amy Schumer’s stand up is too much and I’m not in the mood for Ozark either. You’ll love it because: The talented cast, not to mention.. Jon Hamm in comedy! Gypsy  This psychological thriller drama is not everybody’s cup of tea. The tempo is a bit slow, so I’m not surprised to know Netflix canceled this series 6 weeks after its premiere. But considering it’s been a long time since we saw Naomi Watts’s brilliant acting in series, it’s still a hidden gem. You’ll still like it because: the soundtrack varies from Cyndi Lauper to Cigarettes After Sex! Orange is The New Black This prison comedy drama is based on the real Piper Kerman’s memoir. The 16 Emmy nominations speak for the series itself. Solid cast and strong ensemble, no boring or so-so character. All characters are very interesting to watch, especially because each episode has a flashback of every character’s background before they were in prison.  Why you need to watch it: Jodie Foster directed two episodes in season 1 and 2. The 12 greatest characters on 'Orange Is the New Black' The End of The F***ing World  Can’t decide which one I like more, the story or the soundtrack. Graham Coxon wrote soundtrack for the series, definitely a must watch for Blur fans. The cinematography is fascinating, the color palettes are beautiful, it’s like the love child of Wes Anderson and Valencia Instagram filter. While for the story, it’s either you like it or hate it. Music from The End of the Fucking World Season 1 The Alienist  This psychological thriller drama is set in NY, 1896. In the beginning, I thought it’s just like another Holmes-Watson crime investigating drama. It’s not. Besides Daniel Bruhl’s character who is basically Sherlock without sense of humor and dark personality, the series actually explores more on psychological aspect. Watch it because: the set is breathtaking (the crew built a replica of NY in Budapest), not to mention the costume.. Take the 360 behind the scenes tour here:  Honorable mentions: GLOW  Chewing Gum  Cuckoo  Collateral  Champions  Good Girls  ATypical  Alias Grace

Netflix, a video-on-demand, streaming service. that has produced a variety of original series, that can be considered as must watch. 1.Stranger Things (2016-)  Genre :- Science Fiction - Horror - Period Drama No of seasons :- 3 Language :- English Summary :- Set in a fictional town of Hawkins, Indiana, in early 1980s. where, United States Department of Energy, established, a lab, named as, Hawkins National Laboratory, where they conducts, secret experiments, on human test subjects, most of them were forcefully abducted and they also created a portal, onto, an alternate dimension, called "the Upside Down", which influences the entire town, in a negative way. It also affects the life of few nerdy teenagers, of Hawkins High school and people around them. First Season, is set on 1983, tells the story of, those teenagers, searching for their friend, Will Byers, who was abducted by, a monster from Upside Down, with the help of Will’s mom and town’s police chief, Hopper. At the same time, they encounters a young girl, named, Eleven, who escaped from Hawkins lab, and has the ability of telekenisis. Second Season, is set in, Halloween 1984, where, they have face, a new and greater problem, from Upside Down, with help of old and new allies. Third Season, is set in, 1985, where, a new and old danger looms, along with the opening of new mall in the town. Characters from last season develops more close relationship. Good reasons to watch :- 80s Nostalgia - Stranger Things can be described as a homage to some of the popular 80s pop culture, especially, from the movies like, E.T., Ghostbusters, Back to the future. It was also inspired from the works of Stephen King and several anime and video games.Soundtrack - The music of this series, was composed by, electronic band, Survive, and it looks like, a homage to the artists and composers of 1980s.Performances - Performances of the entire cast was amazing, especially, that of, Millie Bobby Brown, David Harbour, Winona Ryder, Charlie Heaton, are few among them.Other reasons - Atmosphere, Good writing and direction, also it’s horror nature.2.Black Mirror (2011-)  Genre :- Science Fiction- Satire - Psychological thriller - Anthalogy No of seasons :- 5 + Special + Interactive Episode Language :- English Summary :- Inspired by Rod Serlings ‘s media franchise, The Twilight Zone, Black Mirror tells a bunch of different stories, that are a dark reflection of human society, mainly dealing with humanity’s relationship with technology. The series questions our way of living and approach towards the things that we are not yet ready to interact with. All the episodes of the series are believed to be set in the same universe, which is evident from some of the easter eggs in every episodes. Episodes like, The National Anthem, White Christmas, Shut Up and Dance, Hated in the Nation, Arkangel, Black Museum are phenomenal. Good reasons to watch :- Commentary - The series deals with some of the contemporary issues in our society, especially, episodes, like, Waldo Moment, White Bear, National Anthem, Shut up and Dance, Men against Fire, are dealing with our current political and social commentary.Warning - Each episodes serves as a warning to the viewers, especially, millennials, on their dependence on technology and their approach towards the changing society due to it.Stortelling - The entire writing of the series is amazing, the way they build-up the characters, their interaction, all goes hand in hand with each other.Big names - There are a lot of familiar faces, in the show, like Hayley Atwell, Bryce Dallas Howard, Jon Hamm, Hannah John-Kamen, Miley Cyrus, Anthony Mackie,Domhnall Gleeson, Letitia Wright and so on.3.Marvel’s Daredevil (2015–2018)  Genre :- Superhero- Crime Drama - Action No of seasons :- 3 Language :- English Summary :- This series is set in Marvel Cinematic Universe, which means, it shares the continuity with the Marvel movies. It is based upon, the famous Marvel comics superhero, Daredevil, created by Stan Lee and Bill Everett. After the Battle of New York, seen in , The Avengers; New York, is in a pretty bad state, these circumstances, created an opportunity for, various mobsters, thus, increasing the crime rate, in the city, This forced, an enhanced blind lawyer, Matt Murdock, to patrol the streets of Hell’s Kitchen, as Daredevil. First Season, is about, dealing with the secrets of the, underworld, led by, a powerful mobster, Wilson Fisk. Second Season, is about, Murdock trying to balance him life as a superhero by night and a lawyer by day, while, dealing with, a deadlier vigilante, Punisher and her former girlfriend, Elektra Natchios. The character, of Daredevil, later appeared in a crossover series, The Defenders, which tells the story of him teaming up with other superhero vigilantes, like, Luke Cage, Jessica Jones, Iron Fist, to save New York, from the impending doom, caused by, an ancient group of evil ninjas, The Hand. Then, in the third season, Fisk got released from the prison, and, Murdock, went missing after the events of The Defenders, he have to decide whether he has to continue his life as a lawyer or the devil of the Hell’s Kitchen. Good Reasons to watch :- It’s Marvel - It’s created by TV division of Marvel also set in the same universe of popular media franchise ,MCU, the titular character, is one of the most popular Marvel superheroes; the series, doesn’t shy away from, showing the darker and mature side, of MCU, comparing to it’s movies and other series, which, basically, has a lot of lighter elements.Development of characters - Every major characters are well-developed and compelling, especially, Wilson Fisk, due to, which, he is considered as, one of the best MCU villians.Isolated and dark - The very nature, of the series, is enough, to make us watch. darker characters like, Daredevil, needs an isolated space to thrive. This makes the viewers get interested in the other side of the the universe, which we know and love.Epic nature - There are other Marvel-Netflix series, but, what makes, Daredevil, to stand out, is the very nature of the show, as it is having the tone, of a classic superhero story line, hero born out of dire circumstances, cool costume, ready to make sacrifice attitude and so on. Daredevil fits those criteria very well. So, it became a great example of a classic superhero series, that also, respects the source material very well.4. Love, Death and Robots (2019-)  Genre :- Science Fiction-Fantasy-Horror-Comedy-Anthology No of seasons :- 1 Language :- English Summary:- This is an adult anthology animated series, where each episode deals with the thematic connection to the three titular elements, love, death and robots. Each episode has a unique style of animation, and involves various different crews and cast. The series, is the re-imagining, of the famous adult-animated-sci fi, film, Heavy Metal. Some of the episodes, of Love,Death and Robots, have a great potential to become a movie, of it’s own. Akshay 'Apogee' Das's answer to Which one of the Love, Death And Robots shorts would you like to see be a full length feature movie? Episodes like, Sonnie's Edge, The Witness, When the Yogurt Took Over, Beyond the Aquila Rift, Good Hunting, Lucky 13, Alternate Histories, The Secret War are just phenomenal. Good reasons to watch :- Animation- Each episode has a unique style of animation, some of the episode’s animation styles, are completely different from that of many traditional animation, like that of, Disney or Pixar.Diversified storytelling- Each stories are unique and interesting on it’s own, which sometimes, can subvert our expectation for each episodes.Worldbuilding - The way they have set up an imaginary world, in episodes like, Good Hunting, Beyond the Aquila Rift, Shape-Shifters, Secret War, are more than amazing.Gore and Adult nature - The series was inspired from the movie, Heavy Metal, which was, famous for, it’s great deal of graphic violence, sexuality and nudity. The series lived upto it’s predecessor.5. Ghoul (2018)  Genre :- Horror-Thriller No of seasons :- 1 Language :- Hindi Summary :- An Indian miniseries, horror web series, that is based upon the monster, from Arab mythology, Ghoul. Set in a dystopian India, where authoritarian fascist regime has took control over the government, and any form of, resistance, would be brutally crushed. Those who are opposing the government would be, incarcerated, in a special internment camps for “interrogation”. The story follows, Nida Rahim, a newly recruited military officer who is stationed at a covert military detention centre, where she, with several other officers, have to, interrogate Ali Saeed, an eminent resistance leader. But, Ali, turns the tables on his interrogators, exposing their most shameful secrets, also confirming, that he was possessed by a demonic supernatural entity. Good reasons to watch :- Worldbuilding - The very idea, of a story set in a dystopian world, is unique to, Indian Cinema or Television.Performances - Cast is also pretty amazing, the lead actress, Radhika Apte, is a familiar face, who, had acted in movies of several Indian languages.Storytelling- The story has been told in a pretty amazing manner, that makes the viewers get invested in the story.Suspense - The very primary aspect, of the thriller genre, stands out in this series, that keeps the viewers at the edge of our seat.6. Sacred Games (2018-)  Genre :- Crime-Conspiracy thriller-Mystery drama No of Seasons :- 2 Language :- Hindi Summary :- Sacred Games is based upon the critically acclaimed novel, of the same name, by Vikram Chandra. Inspector Sartaj Singh, a troubled police officer, working for Mumbai police, receives an anonymous phone call from Ganesh Gaitonde, a dreaded mob boss, who has missing for last 16 years. He tells Singh to save the city in 25 days, that triggers a chain of events, that causes him to come in contact with the India’s deeply organised crime, religion, politics, espionage, terrorism and entertainment First Season ends with a cliffhanger, which directly, followed by it’s second season. Good reasons to watch :- Storytelling - The entire series is presented, in two parallel tracks, each of them telling equally parallel stories, of two main protagonists.Familiar Faces - There are a lot of familiar faces, most of the main cast, is filled by popular Bollywood actors like, Saif Ali Khan, Nawazuddin Siddiqui, Radhika Apte, Pankaj Tripathi, Elnaaz Norouzi, Kalki Koechlin, Ranvir Shorey, Karan Wahi and so on.Isolated and Dark - Vikram Chandra’s novel requires a platform, that can go hand-in-hand with the isolated and dark nature of book, and they good job on it.Epic Nature - The series has a larger than life story mixed with realism, taking the fact, that it has an isolated and dark, makes the series much more interesting.7. Marvel’s The Punisher (2017–2019)  Genre :- Superhero-Crime Drama No of Seasons :- 2 Language :- English Summary :- Another story, set in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, that acts as a spi-off to the Daredevil Series, based upon the famous Marvel comic character, Punisher, created by Gerry Comway and John Romita Sr. Frank Castle, had gone for a brutal rampage upon, everyone responsible for his family’s death, which earned him, the title, of “Punisher”, all around the New York City. This also made him come in contact with, another vigilante of New York, Daredevil. In First Season, Frank, penalized all of the gangs, like, Kitchen Irish, New York part of Dogs Of Hell and Mexican Cartel, have been accountable for the death of his household and today he's wanting to rebuild their life, from the scrape. He uncovers a bigger conspiracy beyond the thing that was done to him along with his family. In the 2nd period, Frank ended up being having a quite life, until, the tried murder of Amy Bendix, pushed him to decide whether need to continue their life as Punisher or not. Good reasons why you should view :- It’s Marvel - Like, Daredevil, Punisher, being a Marvel property, is enough to grab attention. Also, the fact that, it is set in MCU, is another big reason to watch this series.Development of characters - The characters are all well-developed and relatable, this creates a one of the several plus points of the series.Isolated and Dark - The dark and violent nature of the story, is what every comic fans expect from the characters like, Punisher. The series did a good job in that area.Performances - The performance of the lead actor, Jon Bernthal, was quite amazing, he looks and acts, exactly, like, the Frank Castle from the comic pages. Supporting actors also did a very good job.

There are a lot of options to select from when you consider watching NETFLIX specially after NETFLIX has burst into the TV and movie Production scene. The following are highly recommended TV shows. ( I am going to exclude House of Cards ) Daredevil: For obvious reasons this show is considered as one of the greatest modern day comic book adaptations on small screen. The show is rich in drama, suspense, Action, Character Development and for all other purposes has a commendable acting performances from their lead cast. (USP : I found the use of lighting in it very interesting)Master of None: A complete switch-over from the previous one, great content reeks in each and every episode of master of none. The character development is phenomenal and you seem to care for everyone you see on screen. The stylization of each episode is awesome. And the acting performances from the lead cast is also very good.Black Mirror: Based on near future experiences of mankind where the integration of technology into human lives is the matter under the spotlight. The writing of each episode is very tight and is a great visual experience with thought provoking central material inside each episode.The Crown: If you like good acting chops, Claire Foy will pretty much seal the deal. BoJack HorsemanSense8Stranger thingsNarcosHouse of CardsJessica JonesOzark13 reasons whyMaking a murdererJessica Jones.Although some people find The iron fist and other defender series good, i would not recommend. also the list is not ordered by rank. they all are great shows and are worth anyone’s time.

STRANGER THINGS Season 1 begins with four kids playing “Dungeons and Dragons” in one of their basements . On their way back, one of the kids go missing and as they search for the missing kid, extraordinary mysteries involving secret government experiments, supernatural forces and an unusual little girl are unraveled.  The perfect blend of fantasy and sci fi. The 80s element not only brings back the sweet memories of simpler times but also decreases the chances for loopholes in the plot to some extent. It redefines the overused concept of alternate dimensions and monsters by bringing a scientific aspect and makes all of it further interesting by adding the adequate mix of supernatural element in it. Currently, the series has three seasons and Netflix has recently confirmed the release of a fourth (and possibly final) season. THE HAUNTING OF HILL HOUSE Hugh and Olivia Crane move into the ‘Hill House’ with their children intending to sell it and and build their own house. However, due to unexpected repairs, they are forced to stay longer and start experiencing paranormal phenomena, resulting in Olivia’s death and the rest of the family fleeing the house. Years later, they are reunited and the tragedy strikes once again.  It is not the best horror series I have ever watched or anything but it does have something in it that captivates your interest since the beginning. It doesn’t have an awful lot of jumpscares, so if that’s what you are looking for, this may not be the right one. The plot develops rather slowly, but once you have gotten a strong grip on the characters and how their stay in the house affected each of them personally, the story begins to make more sense. This one has got only one season. Fortunately for the fans, Netflix renewed the series for a second season, titled “the Haunting of Bly Manor”. It will not be a continuation of the original plot though. I AM NOT OKAY WITH THIS Sydney Novak, a 17-year-old teenager living with her mother and younger brother, navigates the complexities of high school, family and her sexuality, while dealing with her new-found superpowers.  This one gave me Stephen King’s “Carrie” feels. It is, in fact, awfully similar to the novel, yet unique. The series is captivating in its own special way. Nothing spectacular yet gripping. It expresses well how hard a teenager tries to fit in a crowd that labels her as an outcast, while having to deal with the emotional stress and anguish of losing a loved one as well as dealing with a set of powers she never knew she had. Although no official announcements were made about a second season, it had a pretty open ending. So, there is definitely hope, I guess. LOCKE AND KEY After their father’s murder, three children move to their ancestral home, filled with mysteries involving reality-altering keys and demonic entities.  Yet another Netflix Original that takes you into a whole another world where demons and keys that can influence reality exists. To be honest, this one didn’t leave much room for character development. Then again, there were too many things that they had to squeeze into the plot in limited time so that the plot makes sense, so I can’t really complain. Somehow, it was still captivating enough and the ending was not at all disappointing. It got the one thing right that most of the others get wrong - the ending. Netflix recently confirmed a second season. 13 REASONS WHY Hannah Baker, a troubled teenager, commits suicide. Weeks after the tragedy, her classmate, Clay, receives a box of recordings made by Hannah explaining the 13 reasons that prompted her to take her life. The mystery unravels as Clay goes on listening to the tapes and comes to know how he became one of the 13 reasons responsible for her death.  The plot focuses on disturbed teens while trying to unveil the mystery behind the rapidly increasing rate of teen suicides. Season 1 was definitely gripping, but I think they pushed it too far by releasing the other seasons with the not-so-great plotlines. (Maybe, they just got carried away by the overwhelming response they received for the first season or whatever). Also, one of the major flaws that found with the plotline was that the story progresses in such a way that even the viewer feels like Hannah had no choice but to kill herself, which is definitely not the kind of message that they should be giving out, particularly when their target audience includes teenagers. Presently, the series has three seasons and the fourth (and final) one is about be released soon. SHADOWHUNTERS Based on Cassandra Clare’s bestselling novel, the story follows the journey of Clarissa Fray, a shadowhunter (part-angel, part-human), who hunts demons. After her mother gets abducted, she is forced to deal with the shadow world and everything that lies within. She relies on fellow shadowhunters, Jace, Alec and Isabelle as well as her childhood friend Simon on her quest to rescue her mother.  Personally, I felt that Lilly Collins gave a better performance as Clary in the movie version of the same. It is not like Katherine McNamara was not convincing in her portrayal as Clarissa Fray. But, when there is someone else who portrayed the same character, you are bound to be compared with each other. If you are looking for something that does justice to the books, sorry, this is not the right one. They have altered the plotline too much for that. It is still worth watching, for the drama, romance and whatnot. The ending was not satisfactory, but limiting the entire plot of the fourth season to a two-hour-episode could not have been that easy. MONEY HEIST (La Casa De Papel) A man recruits eight people in his quest to conduct the world’s biggest heist in history - to print billions of euros in the Royal Mint Of Spain. Things go out of hand, when an investigator, who is just as clever as the mastermind behind the heist, takes up the case.  First of all, this one is not everyone’s cup of tea and you have to be patient for the first few episodes to get some insight into the plot. It is highly entertaining, but, I am sorry, I don’t get what the extreme hype is about. So, if you prefer a series that goes on with the story of a heist, lasting several seasons, Money Heist is exactly what you are looking for. ORANGE IS THE NEW BLACK A privileged New Yorker finds herself in a women’s prison when a past crime catches up with her.  I am watching it right now. So far, so good. Apparently, it has got seven seasons. So, if it is not interesting enough, I won’t be giving a review. If you are looking for Netflix Original series, this is pretty much it, as far as I have seen.

The difficulty with answering this question is that everyone has different tastes when it comes to what they like/dislike in a TV show. There are lots of Netflix hit TV shows, but that’s an easy list to look up. All I can do is give my personal recommendation of some I’ve watched and enjoyed. (Not in any particular order btw). Stranger Things: This is a sci-fi/horror show that’ll remind you quite vividly of Stephen King’s work. It also draws from lots of 80s nostalgia, and plays on a lot of the common tropes found in hit movies like the Goonies and E.T. It’s got a great cast, particularly the child actors. Hemlock Grove: This is an already finished horror/fantasy show. It’s hardly my favorite that I discovered on Netflix but if you like the genre it’s got a pretty interesting take on some of the folklore. It’s very dark, and no one is really heroic in it though, so be prepared for that. Marco Polo: A historical drama where everyone is a lot prettier than they probably were in real life lol. It is NOT historically accurate, but a sort of dramatic retelling of events. So if that bugs you, it’s a no-no. The performances, costumes and sets, and action are really good altogether. Unfortunately, it did get cancelled, so if you don’t want to get invested, that’d make sense. Sense8: Another cancelled show. It’s a sci-fi show created by the makers of the Matrix movies, and is honestly the best thing they’ve come out with since. It’s got a very unique plot, difficult not to give to much away but let’s say it has to do with a sort of psychic connection-It also has lots of government conspiracy stuff, if you like that sort of thing. The cast is great and it’s very much original in it’s concept and presentation. Grace and Frankie: Fantastic comedy staring Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin in the titular roles. Also stars Martin Sheen and Sam Waterson. It’s very funny, but also filled with lots of heartfelt moments. I was able to binge this very quickly, which is rare for me. It’s still going too, several seasons (4, I think, lol) into it. Frontier: I’m still working on this one, only recently discovered it so I can only talk about the first season so far. It’s a historical drama about the fur trade in North America during the 1700s. It stars Jason Momoa, and Landon Liboiron (who is also in Hemlock Grove, hence the name drop). It’s quite well done. I have no idea the level of historical accuracy but again it’s rather gripping. It’s also been renewed for a third season, so it’s not as difficult to “catch up on” than some others would be. Longmire: This originally aired on A&E, but Netflix picked it up a few years ago and it’s final season (5th, I believe) was just released. It’s based off of a book series, and is essentially a modern Western about a sheriff out in rural Wyoming (as if there’s a non-rural Wyoming lol) who’s involved in all sorts of mysteries. It’s fantastically acted imo, and well-written. Good action too, and it’s nice to see a genre that’s rare today represented and modernized. I do think the first three/four seasons are the best personally, but it’s still good. And yes, I still have to finish the last season, but only cause I promised my mother I’d watch it with her :D Making a Murderer: You might have heard about this in the press a bit. It’s a documentary about a true crime case that is still actively going on today. It’s highly controversial, but a very interesting watch if you’re interested whatsoever, of course. Saying anything more would give too much away. Now I’d like to mention the Marvel Netflix shows. Obviously, if you’re not a Marvel fan, or a comic book fan you won’t enjoy these, but if you are, especially if you’ve watched the Marvel movies, I’d recommend all of them to one degree or another. Daredevil: Has two seasons done. Very good overall. Lots of action and well written. I never cared for Daredevil too much but this show made me care. Love the side characters. Vincent D’Onofrio portrays a very menacing Wilson Fisk to perfection. Jessica Jones: Honestly, I didn’t enjoy the first season too much apart from the best of the Marvel Netflix villains, Kilgrave, portrayed by the always great David Tennant. I’ve come to like the titular character more overtime though. Jessica Jones is more of a private detective who just happens to have super powers. Luke Cage: The weakest imo of the Marvel shows, but there are still good parts of it, especially in it’s performances. Again if you like the genre you’d probably still enjoy it. Same goes for… Iron Fist: Definitely the most sloppily put together of the shows, unfortunately. This one caused some controversy and division. You’d have to basically ADORE Marvel/comic books to watch it and be guaranteed to like it. The Defenders: This is a special mini series in which the characters of the previous four mentioned shows team up to defeat a big bad. Essentially, it’s Marvel Netflix Avengers. Obviously, don’t watch unless you’ve watched at least some of the others. You’ll face at least some level of confusion if you don’t watch them all but you’d need to watch at least both seasons of Daredevil to get the most. The Punisher: My personal favorite and the most recent. The Punisher is a vigilante with no qualms about killing. He first appears in Season 2 of Daredevil. You wouldn’t “have” to watch that in order to understand this show but you’d be missing out on a lot of great acting and back story. Jon Bernethal is wonderful in this part and this one is the most realistic and heart wrenching by far.

Daredevil  Genre - Action, Crime and Drama Episodes - 26 Seasons - 2 Runtime - 54 minutes The first in a planned series of shows detailing the Marvel universe, "Daredevil" follows Matt Murdock, attorney by day and vigilante by night. Blinded in an accident as a child, Murdock uses his heightened senses as Daredevil to fight crime on the streets of New York after the sun goes down. While Murdock's day job requires him to believe in the criminal justice system, his alter ego does not follow suit, leading him to take the law into his own hands to protect his Hell's Kitchen neighborhood and the surrounding communities. House of Cards  Genre - Drama Episodes - 65 Seasons - 5 Runtime - 51 minutes Frank Underwood is a Democrat appointed as the Secretary of State. Along with his wife, he sets out on a quest to seek revenge from the people who betrayed him while successfully rising to supremacy. Orange Is the New Black  Genre - Comedy, Crime andDrama Episodes - 65 Seasons - 5 Runtime - 59 minutes Ten years after transporting drug money to Alex, Piper is imprisoned for the crime. The toughness of prison changes her drastically as an individual, compelling her to do the unthinkable. Jessica Jones  Genre - Action, Crime and Drama Episodes - 13 Seasons - 1 Runtime - 56 minutes A former superhero decides to reboot her life by becoming a private investigator. 13 Reasons Why  Genre - Drama and Mystery Episodes - 13 Seasons - 1 Runtime - 60 minutes Newcomer Katherine Langford plays the role of Hannah, a young woman who takes her own life. Two weeks after her tragic death, a classmate named Clay finds a mysterious box on his porch. Inside the box are recordings made by Hannah -- on whom Clay had a crush -- in which she explains the 13 reasons why she chose to commit suicide. If Clay decides to listen to the recordings, he will find out if and how he made the list. This intricate and heart-wrenching tale is told through Clay and Hannah's dual narratives.

My favourite Netflix Original is Sense8. It's written by J. Michael Straczynski (creator of Babylon 5) and Lily and Lana Wachowski (creators of the Matrix). It's about a group of 8 strangers across the world who suddenly become linked telepathically, sharing their thoughts, emotions and skills. They help each other out of various problems while also contending with a corporate/government conspiracy that looks to capture and vivisect them. The show is hard going to begin with, it drops you in at the deep end and asks you to follow 8 simultaneous plotlines, each with three or four unique characters - but around episode 4 everything clicks into place. The show has this incredible vibe of positivity around it which is a real breath of fresh air, especially in SF and Fantasy TV which is frequently grim and gritty, but at the same time remains exciting. I'd also recommend: Orange is the New Black, which is a comedy/drama set in a women's prison. Its based on a book of the real-life experiences of a woman named Piper Kernan, who was arrested as a minor part of a drug smuggling ring with her then-girlfriend, though years after she was involved. The show is entirely fictional after the initial setup, and it follows the lives of the prison inmates, frequently flashing back to their time outside and shows what lead to their arrest and sentencing. Master of None, a sitcom written by and starring Aziz Anziari, about an Indian actor living in New York, dealing with topics like family relations, espcially the cultural gap between people who migrated to the West from impoverished countries and their children, rascism, feminism and the trials of living with your partner. The two Marvel shows: Daredevil and Jessica Jones. Both are crime-centred stories set in the backdrop of the Marvel TV and movie universe. In Daredevil a blind lawyer with a superhuman radar sense takes to the streets at night, coming into contact with an organised crime ring run by the almost-mythical Wilson Fisk. Jessica Jones is about a super powered private investigator who's trying to suppress the months of her life she spent in the thrall of an amoral man named Kilgrave, who's able to control people just by talking to them. Even though she left him for dead when she escaped, he returns and she ends up in direct conflict with him. 2017 EDIT: Updated Lily Wachowski’s name to reflect her coming out as trans.

The Rain The official synopsis from Netflix is: “The world as we know it has ended. Six years after a brutal virus wiped out almost all humans in Scandinavia, two siblings join a group of young survivors and set out to find out whether a new world has begun somewhere else. They all hope that the siblings’ father is somewhere out there with answers. Set free from the rules of civilised society, each of the young members of the group has the freedom to be who they want to be, but they all struggle with their own demons, and the fact that even in a post-apocalyptic world there’s love, jealousy, coming of age, and every problem they thought they’d left behind with the disappearance of the world as they knew it.”[2] This seems like a slow burn dramatic, thrilling and engaging sci-fi mystery story and I am excited for it. Thanks for the question. There is some seriously good stuff on Netflix. Stranger Things. There are 3 seasons of this Duffer Brothers masterpiece of a sci fi show set in regional town in US in the 80s. The show appeals to teenagers and people who lived in the 80s. Its got a great music score, the cast is adorable mix of fresh young talent and old veterans from the 80s like Wynona Rider. It’s about strange disappearances of local town folk due to a secret US military facility in town and some local teenagers solving the mystery and saving the day with help from their adult families later. The writing is fresh and action packed. It has something for everyone. You end up thinking the show cannot get any better and season three comes along and blows you away with the introduction of 80s shopping malls, Russians, and return of the teenage and adult hero’s to save the US and the world. Stranger Things I can’t see how they can top the endin* of season three but I hope we see a season 4. Season 3 features an adorable, clever and hilarious use of the Never Ending Story theme song. This show will charm your socks off.   2. Orange is the New Black. A well written and casted show which survived 7 seasons. Set in a US Federal Women’s prison in roughly current time features a hilarious and dramatic look at life inside the prison with the relationships between inmates, the correctional officers, and rival ethnic and other factions and prison politics. Plenty of nudity, sex scenes, lesbian relationships and focuses mainly around our main character inmate Chapman and her life inside. I didn’t think I would like this show but it’s addictive Orange Is the New Black | Netflix Official Site  3. The Crown. This is a drama/mocumentary about the British Royal Family. It is a lavish production which wreaks of big budget sets and international travel. It starts off with events leading to Queen Elizabeth’s coronation and marrying Prince Philip. Seasons one and two are perfect. Very true to history with some artistic licence to fill the gaps. Prince Philip is played by former Dr Who Matt Smith and the young Queen Claire Foy. The cast changes across the seasons as the Royals age. Season one and two are essentially the same lead cast with a young Prince Philip and Queen Elizabeth and younger Princess Margaret and her relationships. Season 3 is more about a more mature queen and her adolescent children and older Princess Margaret. I prefer Seasons 1 and 2 and would consider them to be perfect. The essence of the young Royals is captured perfectly. Netflix's 'The Crown' has replaced its cast with new actors. Here's how they compare to the original stars.  4. Sex Education. This is gold. Set in an American style high school which could be anywhere, but with British cast, it depicts a teenager whose mother is a sex therapist. The main character lad absorbs his mother’s advice and offers counseling to his school mates so they can succeed in their relationships with other love interests. Naturally, life in a school is complex and what if you start giving advice to someone who could bash your head in and you also share an interest in the same young woman? This is a brilliant show with a cast who are easy to like. The story is very clever and you will fall off the chair laughing. Has Gillian Andersen and many other fresh faces. Sex Education (TV Series 2019– ) - IMDb   5. Good Girls. This was something we found as a time filler between seasons of other shows. It’s a gem in its own right. Features an all star cast. It’s about women whose situations find them being in abusive relationships and barely able to make ends meet to escape their situations. The women, all mothers, perform a one time favour for a crime syndicate laundering counterfeit money. They do so well at it they decide to stay on and find themselves caught up in the syndicate making enemies and getting deeper and deeper in the murky underworld. Worth a watch. You will be hooked. It’s hilarious and very dark.   6. Travelers. Canadian produced and Written by Brad Wright it features Erik McCormack (Will and Grace as the lead) as well as many talented veterans and fresh faces including beautiful Mackenzie Porter and many familiar faces as well pop up along the way. Humans and an artificial intelligence in our apocalyptic future discover how to send the minds of special Traveler agents back through time into people of the 21st century, in an effort to correct the path of humanity and events leading to demise of western civilisation. The consciences sent back In time are able to inhabit the minds of living people, targetting people just before their known historical deaths. The hosts carry in their lives with the Travelers in control of their mind and bodies. One episode features a traveller who is inserted into the mind of a sky diver only minutes before the host is going to die from a skydiving accident and the rest would spoil the plot as it’s one of the cleverest episodes and makes good use of the time travel concept and repeated attempts and reattempts to save the incoming traveler. The show has many subplots focusing on character development, their relationships with other Travellers as well as their inherited hosts relationships which can distract them from mission objectives. Not only do the travellers have to carry out their missions that are sent back to them for the future to perform but have to convince friends and family of the host bodies that the original hosts haven’t changed and appear to live their normal lives avoiding attention. The show feels really well made. iThe scripts are good and plot never dull. It has a mix of established and fresh faced actors who are easy to like or dislike if you are meant to…3 brilliant seasons. i hope there are at least one more but if not, it’s finished on a high note. One of the least appreciated shows on Netflix. Some similarities to Continuum but this is much better. Travelers (2016-2018)

Netflix has brought the famous show “The Boys in the Band” to its streaming site. The Tony award-winning play has travelled from the theater to the small screen, but the core magic of the story is intact as the entire cast returns again to entertain us all. While the show directed by Joe Mantello and produced by Ryan Murphy may feel like a stereotypical story of tall handsome men, but the cast involved in the Broadway film holds much more significance than that. The Broadway special play was actually based on a play directed by Matt Crowley who relayed the humorous drama story about the marginalized community and its struggles. Crowley’s play was met with a tragic end as almost the entire cast of the play lost their lives in the ’80s and ’90s due to the health crisis. The modern adaptation of Crowley’s play, “The Boys in the Band”, is special for a lot of reasons. It not only pays tribute to the extraordinary talent of the marginalized community who unfortunately lost their lives to a cruel disease, but it also inspires the young generation to be confident and proud. Furthermore, the entire cast has their own separate fanbase that will help create social awareness even more. From Big Bang Theory’s Jim Parsons to The Sinner’s Matt Bomer, let us see who plays what in the film. Jim Parsons plays the role of Michael. You may know Jim Parsons for his role as the internationally renowned character “Sheldon Cooper” in the American sitcom “The Big Bang Theory.” He portrays Michael in the play and in the film. Michael is the best friend of Harold and their fights are humorous to watch. He has worked alongside Mantello and Matt Bomer in HBO’s production “The Normal Heart.” Matt Bomer plays the role of Donald. You may know him as the villain Jamie Burns in the hit Netflix’s psychological thriller The Sinner. He plays the role of Michael’s boyfriend, who has every intention to settle down soon. Zachary Quinto portrays Harold. It’s his birthday party that creates the scene for all the drama. Andrew Rannells personifies Larry. He is a popular actor and singer who has acted in movies like The Intern, A Simple Favor, and Why Him. Robin de Jesus plays the role of Emory. Robin de Jesús has earned a Tony nomination for his performance in Boys in the Band. He has worked in a number of plays and movies. Michael Benjamin Washington as Bernard. You may also know him from another Netflix drama series-Ratched. He is also known for his works in the plays. Brian Hutchison portrays Alan. Brian Hutchison is an American actor who has made many appearances on American television. All in all, Netflix’s adaptation of this touching broadway show will tug at your heartstrings.
