All of these answers are obviously subjective, but there’s a good list developing. I’ll limit myself to Netflix Originals, because as great as The Good Place is, if it’s licensed, it can go away any time. That said, because Netflix produced the fourth season of Arrested Development, I think that the first three seasons (which are far superior) will be streaming for a while. A good mix of smart and stupid humor. For good family suspense, you can’t beat Stranger Things. I’ve written elsewhere on how it was a great family bonding experience. If you like superhero stuff, season 1 of Daredevil and Jessica Jones both had some great performances. Right now, the show I keep telling people about is American Vandal. It’s a parody of true-crime shows, but it’s more than that. Like any of these recommendations, watch one episode and decide if it works for you. Finally, Netflix is producing a lot of standup specials. I like Mike Birbiglia and Dave Chappelle and Rory Scoville, but one of the funniest is the 25 minute set by Nate Bargatze from The Standups.

Yesterday was significant. In this dreary abyss of endless quarantine time passing in a strange, warped like fashion – I finally managed to do something I felt grateful for when it ended. I saw the season 2 of the British dark-comedy show Afterlife.   Its a story about a man in his 50s, Tony Jones, whose wife, Lisa, dies from cancer. Theirs was an amazing marriage, the “best one possible” as he so promptly describes several times in the show. He is absolutely shattered as a result of it, as Lisa was the single best thing, his only accomplishment according to him, in his life. The couple and their German Shepherd, Brandy, lived in small-town called Tambury in East Sussex, England. He works as an employee in a 6-member team of Tambury Gazette, the local newspaper printing ridiculous stories no one really cares about. His easy-to-go and generally happy nature takes a colossal hit when his wife dies, and he turns immensely suicidal. He only manages to not pop in an entire bottle of sleeping pills because of his dog, who comes to him whenever she hears him crying over videos of his and Lisa’s life together before she died as well as video recordings she secretly made for him in the hospital. The dog, Brandy, is quite intelligent and understands that Tony is considering harming himself and barks, jumps, and whines incessantly until Tony keeps the bottle of pills away. He claims several times in the show that if not for the dog, he’d have killed himself by now. He also decides to live long enough to punish the world for existing (while his wife is dead) by doing and saying whatever he feels like, but it gets tricky when his friends try to save him from this downward spiral.   Tony and Brandy Tony also visits his aged father, Ray, who’s suffering from advanced Alzheimer’s, every single day in the local Care Home. Ray doesn’t even recognize him most of the time, but in the Care Home is where he meets Emma, the nurse who takes care of his father. They hit off, but Emma tells him that he’s obviously and understandably still very much hung over his wife and that she cannot pursue a relationship this way. They continue to meet every day in the Care Home but don’t start a relationship. When Ray dies, at the end of season 2, Tony realizes he cannot enter into a relationship with Emma without feeling as if he’s cheating on Lisa, and Emma fully understands that. After Ray’s funeral, Tony suggests that they can continue like this, seeing each other every day like this without ‘labeling summat’, in a manner of Groundhog day. It is a difficult proposition for Emma, who is reluctant due to the more-than-friendship but less-than-commitment nature of his proposition, but she later comes around and agrees to the “Groundhog day”. This bit is portrayed beautifully in the show and makes you root for them all through the show.   Tony and Emma Tony’s newspaper office has Matt, his brother-in-law, and close friend, as his boss whose marriage is crumbling apart. His coworkers include Kath, the attractive, superstitious advertising head who has a crush on Matt; Sandy, the new 20-year old new journo-in-training who lives with her sick, non-working parents and depends on this job as a crutch from her miserable life; Lenny, Tony’s best friend and colleague with whom he goes to people’s houses to cover nonsensical stories for their newspaper. Visuals of stories Tony and Lenny cover — a 50-year-old man who imagines himself as an 8-year old school girl and dresses up as such, much to the displeasure and distress of his wife and daughter; or an aged woman whose claims of how she can communicate to cats after her husband and daughter died are a juvenile way of telling her unhappy story to the world; or a 90-year old man who’s so blind he ends up putting his mail in a dog shit-box for a year and is despairing and lonely over not having received a response from a long-distance friend of his — are quite peculiar to watch, bringing to Tony’s attention as well as ours to how much of a masked sorrow there is in everyone’s life and struggle is omnipresent and to the extent people tend to become powerless and helpless as they get older. This eventually leads him to show compassion to others instead of constant resentful remarks.   Tony and his work squad Tony also befriends a sex-worker, Roxy, whom he hires to clean his kitchen(!) a couple of days after Lisa’s demise, and who laters comes on to check in on him every day and listen to him reminisce about Lisa. He also meets a kind widow Ann in the graveyard where Lisa is buried. Tony shares updates on his life and his mental health with her, and she recalls her own experiences and imparts wisdom, insight, and perspective to him at a time when he needs it the most. She sort of acts as a therapist for him, listening to the daily happenings of his life and helping him grieve properly for his dead wife. Their conversations in the well-lit, scenic graveyard (Great use of symbolism, turning a place setting as gloomy and dispiriting as a graveyard into a place for new friendships and fresh perspectives) are extremely beautiful and inspiring. Ann is full of compassion and love towards life and she talks to Tony in a very patient and non-judging manner, guiding him to a life without his one true love. She also plays a role in helping him keep off killing himself and shows him that despite everything, continue to live is worth it and how helping and connecting to others will do him a ton of good.   Tony and Ann So, in a way, she acts as an usher to the theatre of his life, eventually affecting his behavior towards others, modifying them from bitter, While initially full of cruel and sarcastic remarks, bitter outlook on everything, and very understandable hatred of others and himself(on the pretext of them being alive, while his wife is very much dead), he begins to get a little bit better as his life continues. Like any sort of real progress over a massive tragedy in one’s life, he often regresses and has a breakdown in his bedroom, watching Lisa’s videos over and over again. The path to recovery is arduous and full of thorns and every day feels like a struggle to get through. And like any realistic portrayal of trauma, even at the end of season 2, he’s very much suicidal as he was at the beginning of season 1. Very often you can be back to right where you started, or worse. The writing, direction, and acting are splendid, and the actor who plays Tony, Ricky Gervais, did all the three of those. It handles a subject as deeply sad as cancer and depression in a very sensitive yet up-front way and deals with the real-life tragedies of Tony as well as the others in his life in a very poignant manner and we cannot help but pause the playback for a few seconds and wonder at the brilliant words just spoken(very, very often by Ann) and we reflect at the sadness and pain in our lives and take away a lot of the wisdom imparted in the show while stealing away quite a few laughs because it’s a dark comedy after all!!!   This show is especially healing for those of us struggling with mental health. The way the show transports us to the slow-paced small-town life of Tambury and it’s modest, simple people and their common yet bigger-than-life struggles make you pause and reflect on the difficulties in your own life and how connected we all are to each other with the myriad challenges we face in our lives. It compels us to admit how a little bit of compassion can go an extremely long way at making each others lives better. Because eventually, kindness and compassion are what make life worth living in the face of monstrous setbacks and trauma.   This show will be one of the most touching you’ll ever watch, and it’ll sure as hell make the best of us tear up every now and then. Fin.

Alexa and Katie. Not many TV series have a storyline revolving around Cancer. That too definitely not a comedy series. -No Spoilers Ahead- It is a beautiful sitcom that helps you understand what goes on in the mind of a cancer fighter/survivor and the people around them. Cancer is already such a sensitive subject and to portray it in a sitcom revolving around high school, without going overboard on the humour or the pain element is a really difficult thing to do. And this series does that beautifully. Sure there are lots of artificial elements and some over the top humour, but how else do you humour-coat cancer yet get the struggles and the victories through? It also shows how deep friendships can run and how it does not just affect an individual, but everyone around them. The best thing about the show is how it shows cancer as a phase of your life that you can outgrow, but a phase you need to be wary of through all your living days. This series is really a must-watch in the Indian context because support groups for cancer fighters/survivors are difficult to come by. And support groups for the families of people with cancer doesn’t exist. This series will enlighten you beautifully how much space you need to give the patient and how much you need to keep away. It might not focus too much on the physical aspect of things, but it does a really good job of demonstrating the emotional aspect in a non-serious but effective way. It also shows the need to prove yourself after you have come out of this ordeal because you are always left feeling like Cancer took a major part of your life and how you are no longer the person you used to be. It deals beautifully with how difficult it is to really talk about it even though you know kicking cancers butt was probably the bravest thing you ever did. To all the people out there, if you have ever been diagnosed with the C-word, or have friends or family fighting cancer, this is one show you definitely can’t miss.

She-Ra and the Princesses of Power Most people don’t know this show but it’s my favourite Netflix series of ALL TIME. Warning: spoilers for seasons 1–4 and early season 5 SEASONS: 5 EPISODES: 52 RUNNING TIME (or whatever the f it was called): 24mins SUMMARY/PLOT: This show follows an orphan called Adora (around 17/18 at the start of the series and 20/21 at the end of it), who has grown up in the Horde (one of the forces of Etheria, the planet they live on, the other being the Rebellion). Until one day after crash-landing a skiff in the Whispering Woods she finds a magic sword that transforms her into the mythical warrior She-Ra. She met one teenager (Glimmer) and a guy around her age (Bow) and they tell her about the Horde’s evil doings. Adora then makes a decision to leave the Horde and join the Rebellion. Favourite episodes from each season: S1: The Battle of Bright Moon. An amazing finale to cap off the first season. While Adora, Glimmer, and Bow’s attempt to reform the Princess Alliance failed, the Horde charged in with a battle. The rest of the princesses charged in too, and soon realised that “teamwork makes the dream work”. S2: Roll With It. This episode was also about teamwork. Adora, Glimmer, Bow, and the rest of the princesses wanted to formulate an attack plan on the Horde, but each of the princesses had their own idea. Finally, they decided to use all of them, to amazing results. S3: The Price of Power. Fabulous season premiere, so funny too. Some memorable phrases include: “You must be Glimmer’s mother. I can tell by the way your voice grows shrill when you scream.” “How dare you!!” S4: I have many favourite episodes in this season, including Protocol, Mer-mysteries, Hero, and Fractures. I also liked the season finale, where Adora was able to break her sword. I already knew that, in like five episodes’ time, she was gonna obtain a new one (coz I already searched it) S5: This I cannot decide as I have not finished the season yet. But one of my favs was Stranded I hope you like this show.

If you like some documentary, I recommend you to watch Chef’s Table – Netflix produces it. There are three seasons available now. Each single episode of the series profile a single world-renowned chef that shows us their place of work – restaurants. The most talented chefs of all of the World talk about their experience and how their life looks like on a daily basis. The way of recording the chefs and showing us the best dishes, that are masterpieces, is very professional. You can find out what’s inside the kitchens and minds of the international culinary stars. All of these details make this series absorbing, not only for those who loves cooking, but also for people that love to travel, explore and get to know other lifestyles. The directors, in the first section of series, take us on the trip to Modena, in Italy and shows us the restaurant Osteria Francescana, owned and run by chef Massimo Bottura. The restaurant is rated with tree stars by the Michelin Guide and considered as one of the best restaurants in Italy. The Chef’s Table is Emmy-nominated docuseries. If you want to taste a foretaste, the trailer is available on Netflix official site.

I recommend the original Brazilian Netflix series called 3%. The language is in Portuguese with the options of having English language dubbed in or subtitles. I just finished seasons 1-3. The show is about a future Earth with an impoverished inland and a luxurious island called the Offshore that individuals have the opportunity to become residents of if they pass all tests in a competition called the Process when they turn 20 years old. During the Process, the 20 year olds go through various critical thinking and other tests set up by officials of the Offshore. Candidates either pass or fail each test. Those who pass all tests go to the Offshore, but at a cost-they need to be sterilized first, since the Offshore requires it. Only 3% of the 20 year old candidates pass all tests and make it to the Offshore. Those who fail the Process are stuck on the impoverished inland forever. The Offshore is attractive to the inlanders, since it has resources that are not available or in low supply on the inland such as clean drinking water, a large variety and supply of healthy food, technology, medicine, low crime rate, good housing, and a pleasant environment. This show has a great cast of dynamic characters with unique personalities and interesting flashbacks to the past. Ezequiel is the Offshore official who leads the Process that the main characters of Michele, Joana, Rafael, Fernando, and Marco participate in. Michele and Rafael pass the Process and are transported to the Offshore via submarine, while Joana, Fernando, and Marco don’t pass and remain on the inland. Michele, Rafael, Joana, Fernando, and Ezequiel were all previously involved with the opposition military group on the inland called the Cause. The Cause opposes the Offshore’s greediness in not sharing its resources with the needy inland, believes the Process is unfair, and rebels against it. The Offshore has its own militia led by Marcela to fight against the Cause. After working very hard to pass the Process to get to the Offshore, Michele and Rafael realize they don’t fit in with the Offshore’s philosophies and eventually both decide to leave the Offshore. Michele creates a third community called the Shell in the remote desert. The Shell’s motto is everyone is accepted and nobody is rejected (unlike the Process which rejects people from going to the Offshore). The Offshore is against the Shell and its militia tries to sabotage and take control of it. When the Shell’s residents learn the Offshore sabotaged it, they fight against and defeat the Offshore militia and regain control of the Shell. This show is full of action, drama, mystery, and unexpected twists/surprises. I look forward to the final season 4 in August 2020 to see if the Shell will defeat the rest of the militia on the Offshore to bring an end to the Process and restore peace and fairness for everyone.

Hey.. These are some of my favourite Netflix series  Stranger Things is an American science fiction-horror web television series created, written, and directed by the Duffer Brothers. This series is developed as a mix of investigative drama alongside supernatural elements portrayed with childlike sensibilities.  Sacred Games is an Indian web television series based on Vikram Chandra's 2006 thriller novel of the same name, it is also the first Netflix original from India Sartaj Singh (Saif Ali Khan) is a troubled police officer in Mumbai who receives a phone call from gangster Ganesh Gaitonde (Nawazuddin Siddiqui), who tells him to save the city within 25 days.  House of Cards is an American political thriller web television series created by Beau Willimon. House of Cards is set in Washington, D.C. and is the story of Congressman Frank Underwood (Kevin Spacey), a Democrat from South Carolina's 5th congressional district and House Majority Whip. He is passed over for appointment as Secretary of State, so he initiates an elaborate plan to attain power, aided by his wife Claire Underwood (Robin Wright)  Orange Is the New Black (sometimes abbreviated to OITNB) is an American comedy-drama web television series created by Jenji Kohan  Mindhunter is an American crime drama web television series created by Joe Penhall, based on the true crime book Mindhunter: Inside the FBI's Elite Serial Crime Unit written by John E. Douglas and Mark Olshaker. Catching a criminal often requires the authorities to get inside the villain's mind to figure out how he thinks. That's the job of FBI agents Holden Ford and Bill Tench. They attempt to understand and catch serial killers by studying their damaged psyches. Keep watching :) Source: Wikipedia

Midnight Diner: Tokyo Stories, probably the most heartwarming series on Netflix  Rotten Tomatoes: 100% IMDB: 8.3 There are tons of series on the internet out there, but I have hardly ever come across anything like this one. Midnight Diner is an anthology which presents human connection in the most amazing way. Set in Tokyo, Japan this series is about a late-night-diner (that opens from 12 am to 7 am) where the characters frequently visit and their life stories unfold there.  The official trailer of ‘Midnight Diner: Tokyo Stories” You instantly fall in love with the Master (owner) of the diner and the atmosphere his place has. The characters that visit him make a place in your heart without even making you realize it. And their stories make you realize that irrespective of the countries & cultures we live in, we are all the same and life treats humans similarly in a different way at different places. You fall in love with their stories and feel happy by when an episode ends. If you have ever read books by Japanese authors you already have an idea of how simple yet beautiful Japanese storytelling is. And this series is a perfect example of it. If you want to watch something different than the usual stuff out there, watch this series. If you want to have 30 mins of your life spent on learning more about human emotions, watch this series. And if you want to fall in love with the Japanese (people, food, culture, storytelling) watch this series. PS: The series is in Japanese with English subtitles. But you will love it anyway. Let’s start with my favourite:  Trollhunters is a Netflix/Dreamworks collaboration that is both created and executively produced by Guillermo Del Toro, and stars Anton Yelchin (in his final role), Kelsey Grammar, Mark Hamill and Tom Hiddleston. I would recommend watching the first two episodes to see if you are interested. Dirk Gently’s Holistic Detective Agency:  The 2-season show stars Samuel Barnett and Elijah Wood in their respective roles as the story takes turns of combining the elements of shows Doctor Who with Disney’s Once Upon A Time on a sci-fi detective story, whose main character relies on his uncontrollable ability to relate things to each other. The first episode should be able to satisfy your interests. And finally, F is For Family:  This adult-oriented animated Netflix show focuses on the story of Frank Murphy, a former US veteran who participated in the Korean War and now feels cursed to live with his family. The first season takes some getting used to, as it features some pretty heavy themes involving verbal and drug abuse. Overall, the show manages to maintain its interest over the course of two seasons and would recommend it if you are in the mood for something verbally violent.

First it is Stranger Things 1 / 2 / 3 (2016-)  Dropping announced on Netflix last month, the good Netflix series Stanger Things has already received acclaims and praises beyond measure. Created by the Duffer Brothers, the show stars Winona Ryder, David Harbour, Finn Wolfhard, Millie Bobby Brown, and a whole gang of soon-to-be child stars. To call it a good series on Netflix would be an understatement. It is, objectively speaking, one of the best TV shows ever made. Paying tribute to cult classic horror movies of the ‘80s, Stranger Things is so much more than just a good a show. The series starts with the disappearance of Will Byers. It then focuses on three groups of people, all trying to get the little boy back. His friends, his mother, and his brother all try to figure out what happened to Will. But things become even more complicated when the kids find a little girl escaped from a secret laboratory. The second one is Sherlock 1 /2 /3 /4  Some of the most famous good TV series on Netflix, Sherlock is a crime/drama TV show based on the famous detective stories of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. The series is starring Benedict Cumberbatch as Sherlock and Martin Freeman as Dr. Watson. This good Netflix series is a modernized version of the famous Sherlock story. The action is taking place in 21st century London and follows Sherlock as he works his talent while solving crimes and fighting his fierce enemies.

My favorite Netflix original is Bojack Horseman.  It's hilarious and dark in equal measure. Bojack is a horse who's a former sitcom star that now wiles away his life in a Hollywood mansion bitter and resentful. There are seeds of the better person (horse?) he desperately wants to believe – and wants other people to believe – he can be. But when the chips are down Bojack can be counted on to make the wrong choices, let his pettiness or insecurity do the thinking for him. The show manages to be surreal, funny, packed with visual gags, depressing, warm, relatable and very human. It also has an amazing title sequence with music by Patrick Carney of The Black Keys.  As well as Bojack there's a great cast of supporting characters – Mr Peanutbutter Bojack's constantly cheerful old sitcom rival (a Labrador), Princess Caroline Bojack's agent and former girlfriend (a cat), Vincent Adultman (three kids in a trenchcoat who date Princess Caroline), Wanda Pierce (an owl played by Lisa Kudrow), Neal McBeal the Navy Seal.

Drama- Alias Grace Based on a Margaret Atwood novel, this compelling mystery series involves a real murder case from the 1840s, a case that obsessed the citizens of Canada for decades. Sarah Gadon is striking as Grace, who may or may not have been complicit in a somewhat ghastly crime. You want to believe her, but something holds you back. Her luminous blue eyes seem to be hiding something.  Comedy- Santa Clarita Diet Hilarious sendup of Zombie tropes. Drew Barrymore and the supporting cast are terrific, but the real surprise in Timothy Olyphant, previously known for portraying strong, rather dangerous characters. He’s a scream in this thing, delivering throwaway lines that land with riotous impact again and again.  Documentary- Dirty Money Eye opening series about corruption in capitalism and what it’s costing regular folks. It gives you a blueprint that clearly puts into focus things you might have suspected, but couldn’t quite correlate due to information overload. This incisive exercise in film journalism brushes aside much of the smoke and mirrors and goes for what’s at the heart of various economic injustices and inequities.

Delhi Crime We have experienced the Nirbhaya gang rape and murder case, we have all been affected by it. Now it's time to hear it form the point of view of the police who caught these rapists. The series is an accurate description of the police and their struggles in coping with an increasing hostility against them after the heinous crime. The police caught all six accused in five days. In 2012, we were so quick to blame the police. But it is also important to realise that they are nothing but the products of an underpaid, overworked and underemployed system. We assume all police officers are snobs lazing around all day in police stations. We assume DCPs and Police Commissioners are corrupt fraudsters who would do anything for a few bucks. This image, although true in a few cases isn't universal. In fact, I believe there are far more sincere police officers in the country than there are the insincere, corrupt snobs. Delhi Crime tells us the stories of the good cops, those who work for five days straight, who stay with the victims until the case is solved and those who travel around the country to catch the accused. The psychology of the rapists behind committing this crime is also addressed. The lack of proper sex education, socio-economic barriers and a misogynistic mentality make them vulnerable to committing such crimes without regrets. The actors have done a wonderful job. The series shatters our perspective, and compels us to think, making it a must watch.  Today Nirbhaya's rapists breathed their last and I would like to thank the police officers who did their job right.

My favorite Netflix original would be Narcos, but I would consider only the first 2 seasons. The show presents the story of Pablo Escobar, the most known cocaine dealer and one of the most wanted men in the 80’s.  The first season starts by presenting how the drug lord created his empire and the continuous race to between him and the Colombian government. I don’t want to over-promote it, but I will assure you it will worth watching. For more plot summaries, check out this article. If the first 2 seasons focused on the life of Pablo Escobar, the third one is about the Cali Cartel story and how Pablo’s men want to change the way they do business. As for the 4th season, rumors say that it will follow the nowadays Mexican cartels war with the American government. I personally am not that hyped about this change, but it may change into a good refresh of the series.

The most entertaining is probably Stranger Things. Don’t get me wrong, there are better ones. House of Cards is more clever, Orange is the New Black is more funny, The OA is more visually impressive, Love is more down-to-earth and has better characters. But Stranger Things, in terms of pure entertainment value, is better than all of these. The story isn’t very original, the characters tend to be a bit caricatured and made for convenience, and the style seems to have been the focus over the plot. But that doesn’t matter because it’s brilliantly executed and is an absolute delight to watch. The direction is superb, the actors are all fantastic and I’ve never been drawn into a series as much in my life. It’s not perfect, but it’s damn fine entertainment.

‘You’ This stalker-drama starring Penn Badgley will have you hooked from the very first episode, whether you like it or not. The sociopathic Joe (Badgley) develops obsessive crushes, stalking his victims as he woos them, and inevitably digging himself a hole that he (and the women he follows) can’t get out of. And weirdly enough, this show is kind of…funny? Just trust us. ‘Dead to Me’ Christina Applegate and Linda Cardellini star in Dead to Me, a dark comedy about a recent widow who makes an unlikely friend at a grief support group. Season 1 is a wild ride whose final episode left us reeling — so catch up now before Season 2 hits Netflix in May. ‘Hollywood’ Ryan Murphy’s long-awaited Hollywood is finally here, showing you Los Angeles in the 1940s like you’ve never seen it. As usual, he focuses his story on those historically disempowered, and looks at what happened to women of color who tried to carve a place for themselves in Hollywood.

I think it’s an unpopular opinion, given the recent negative reviews, but I absolutely adore Friends from College. Each episode made me laugh out loud. The jokes were funny and weird. At the same time, the show made some smart observations about what it’s like to try to be an adult and act “grown up”. I’ve heard complaints that the characters aren’t likable enough, but I found them to be quite relatable. I like that the show has characters who are both flawed and endearing. My favorite character is Nick. I don’t want to get too much into spoilers, but there’s a moment where my heart breaks for him. Despite having a trust fund and a propensity to date younger women, he is just as capable of having emotions and getting hurt.

South African actress Pearl Thusi believes her star turn on Queen Sono, the first African original television series ordered by Netflix, will “change the game for every artist on this continent,” as she tweeted when plans for the show were announcedin December 2018. Thusi’s hope (and that of others) is that this series, which goes into production this year, will alter Africa’s place on the entertainment landscape. Sono features Thusi as a secret agent who juggles crime fighting with the ebb and flow of her personal life. Thusi, who also starred in the ABC-TV show Quantico, will be reunited with director Kagiso Lediga and executive producer Tamsin Andersson, both South Africans. The trio previously worked together on Catching Feelings, a romantic drama. Erik Barmack, Netflix’s vice president for international originals, told The Hollywood reporter that the network is “delighted” by the new series, and “super excited” to bring this distinctly South African tale to life. “Over time our roots will get deeper in Africa and South Africa,” Barmack told THR, “and we’re moving pretty quickly to that now, and plan to invest more in local content.” You can read more about this on my blog.

If you like Game of Thrones and Sci-Fi, I definitely recommend The Expanse. It’s a bit like Game of Thrones in space, but with way less violence and nudity and death in general (altough still having a pretty high death toll). Its budget wasn’t so high, and you can see that, but it makes great use of what it has. The few CGI-shots we get to see are gorgeous, and the set design is really cool, too. Season 2 has a higher budget, so we get more space battles and CGI-landscapes. I really love the story, even though the various arcs are hard to follow sometimes. The protagonists are interesting, flawed but still likeable (no Mary Sues here), and undergo some really nice character development.

Trial by Media It is a documentary series analysing the famous court cases that were extensively influenced by media coverage. This show was an eye opener. I was unaware of the fact that behind these court cases there are so many external factors that play a role in taking the decisions. It gives a very raw and an honest picture of the legal system and how so many lives are effected by the influence and interference of media. Throughout the show I kept on switching sides which shows how compelling both the sides are and it also shows how sometimes people were compelled to believe what they were told and not the actual facts. If you are someone who loves to watch crime stories or someone who is interested in knowing the truth about the media and the legal system, this show is for you.

My vote is for Unsolved.  Unsolved is an American true crime anthology television series. The first season is based on the murders of rappers Tupac Shakur and Biggie Smalls in the late-1990s. The 10-episode season is titled The Murders of Tupac and the Notorious B.I.G. and chronicles the dual police investigations of Detective Greg Kading (John Duhamel) and Detective Russell Poole (Jimmi Simpson) into the controversial murders of two of the rap industry's most legendary players, Tupac (Marcc Rose) and Biggie (Wavyy Jonez). I thought this show was well scripted, as well, the actors who played Biggie and Tupac were very convincing. The show helped to explain why the murders were, and still are, impossible to solve due to the constant issues and/or scandals along the way. The previous Tupac movie (All Eyez on Me) and Biggie movie (Notorious) were both pretty bad (and critic scores supported this) so I was finally happy to watch something true to the actual story with a much better script. I’d highly recommend checking this out.  Ratings IMDB  Rotten Tomatoes

Black Mirror, and start with one of these three episodes: USS Callister, Nosedive, or White Bear. Pick one that sounds good. They’re quite different from each other. Why: It’s an anthology, so you don’t need to watch the episodes in order - you can pick any episode by the description that best fits your current mood. The worst episodes are still better-than-average TV, and the best episodes are fantastic. You’ll want to watch many of the episodes twice to catch details you missed, which is great when you want to introduce the series to friends or family.

Wild Wild Country - When the world's most controversial guru builds a utopian city deep in the Oregon desert, conflict with the locals escalates into a national scandal. A true story. Cartel Land - Filmmaker Matthew Heineman examines the state of the ongoing drug problem along the U.S.-Mexican border.

An original series on Netflix will be one of those series which they produced themselves, and not made by other networks. Now, there’s a catch. “Netflix Originals” change from place to place. THe shows that Netflix produces are always Netflix originals, everywhere. But the shows that Netflix has exclusive rights for a region are also shown as Netflix originals there, for example, the Syfy show THE EXPANSE is shown as a Netflix original in India(my country) whereas its not made by Netflix at all
